metadata.title: Re-synthesis of nano-structured LiFePO4/graphene composite derived from spent lithium-ion battery for booming electric vehicle application

Re-synthesis of nano-structured LiFePO4/graphene composite derived from spent lithium-ion battery for booming electric vehicle application
Wei Songa,1, Jianwen Liua,∗, Lei Youa,1, Shiquan Wanga, Qinwen Zhoua, Yinglong Gaoa, Ruonan Yina, Wenjia Xua, Zaiping Guoa,b,∗∗
aHubei Collaborative Innovation Center for Advanced Organic Chemical Materials & Ministry of Educational Key Laboratory for the Synthesis and Application of Organic Functional, Molecules & College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Hubei University, No. 368 Youyi Avenue, Wuchang District, Wuhan, Hubei 430062, China b Institute for Superconducting and Electronic Materials, Australian Institute for Innovative Materials, University of Wollongong Innovation Campus, North Wollongong, NSW, 2522, Australia
H I G H L I G H T S
• A novel closed-loop regeneration process from spent LiFePO4 battery is proposed. • Spent LiFePO4 cathode is regenerated through Li+ compensation and reshaping. • The regenerated LiFePO4/RGO composites shows better prosperities in EVs/HEVs.
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Spent lithium ion batteries Nanostructured LiFePO4/Graphene composite Hydrothermal synthesis Lithium compensation Electric vehicle application
A B S T R A C T
Currently extensive attentions on application of LiFePO4 batteries in electric vehicles are attracted to the researchers. Owing to the high cost of raw materials and burdensome preparation process, the re-synthesis of LiFePO4 from spent batteries becomes an economical and convenient way. Herein, a novel closed-loop regeneration process simultaneously from spent LiFePO4 cathode and graphite anode is proposed. Spent LiFePO4 cathode material is first successfully regenerated through Li+ compensation and structure reshaping via hydrothermal method, and then graphene oxide is recovered from spent graphite anode via Hummers method. The as-regenerated LiFePO4/reduced graphene oxide composites present spherical morphology, smaller and more uniform particles. The composite mode of LiFePO4 and graphene includes LiFePO4 distributing in the interlayer structure of graphene and the graphene evenly covering on the surface of the particles. The regenerated LiFePO4/reduced graphene oxide batteries exhibit reversible capacities of 162.6 mAhg−1 and high columbic efficiency, stable cycle performances at 0.2 and 1C and excellent rate capacity. Through comparison, the regenerated LiFePO4/reduced graphene oxide composites from hydrothermal process shows better prosperities than those of regenerated LiFePO4 from solid phase roasting method whatever electrochemical properties or economical efficiency in the booming electric vehicles and hybrid electric vehicles industrialization.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Currently larger demands for power batteries in electronic products, such as digital cameras, laptop and electric vehicles (EVs), have been enormously increased. It is forecasted that there will be a booming electronic era with the global market of lithium ion batteries (LIBs)
close to $32 billion in 2020 [1–8]. Recently, LiFePO4 batteries have been widely used in EVs and hybrid EVs (HEVs) due to their stable cycling performance, environmental compatibility, high safety and thermal stability. It has been predicted that more than 100,000 tons of LiFePO4 materials will be used in LiFePO4 batteries in 2020 on account of the rapid development of EVs and HEVs [9–13]. However the

continuous growth of LiFePO4 batteries and human diminished environmental consciousness significantly lead to adverse effects on the resource shortage and environmental pollution [14–17].
As we know, the main disadvantages of LiFePO4 material lie in its low tap density and lithium ion diffusion rate, etc [18,19]. To improve ion diffusion rate and electron conductivity, many methods have been reported, such as the doping of the conductive agent [20], carboncoating [21–23], and particle-size controlling [24]. For example, carbon nanotubes were used as a novel carbon source to enhance the electronic conductivity of LiFePO4 because of its excellent electronic conductivity and network structure [25,26]. Yang et al. prepared a 3D hierarchical self-assembled LiFePO4/graphene hybrid network by using a facile template-free sol-gel method and its reversible capacity reached 146 mAhg−1 at 0.1C after 100 cycles [27]. Song et al. synthesized uniform graphitic carbon coated LiFePO4 nano-plates, which exhibited superior electrochemical performances with outstanding cycling stability at high rates [28]. However it can be observed from above literature, much less attention has been paid to the raw materials whether their cost is high or preparation process is burdensome [26]. Actually, the raw materials for the production of LiFePO4 are mainly distributed in Australia and South America, which disadvantages mainly lie in the unbalanced geographical distribution and exhaustive exploitation. The recycling of LiFePO4 from “municipal minerals” such as spent batteries has become an economical and convenient way.
Spent LiFePO4 recycling processes are mainly intricate energy-intensive methods, involving the solid phase roasting and hydrometallurgical leaching process. During the solid phase roasting process, the spent LiFePO4 regeneration are effected by heating rate, calcination temperature and calcination time [29,30]. Liu et al. have reported regenerated LiFePO4 can reach 120 mAhg−1 using a solid phase sintering method by adding fresh LiFePO4 [31]. Chen et al. have developed a solid phase recycling process to eliminate impurity phases, such as FePO4, Fe2O3, P2O5 and Li3PO4 of spent LiFePO4 materials at 650 °C [29]. Li et al. found that spent cathode with Li2CO3 regenerated at 650 °C displayed better electrochemical performance comparing with other calcination temperature [30]. The hydrometallurgical leaching is the most pervasive chemical technology to recycle valuable metal from LIBs [32]. Li et al. have proposed a novel process for recycling Li, Fe and P elements by adjusting H2SO4 concentration, H2O2/Li molar ratio, and reaction temperature, etc [33]. Bian et al. used phosphoric acid to leach spent LiFePO4 to obtain FePO4·2H2O hierarchical micro-flowers,
then mixed Li2CO3 and glucose to re-synthesized LiFePO4/C composite in N2 atmosphere via solid phase calcination process [34].
Based on above literature, high temperature is required in the solid phase roasting process which consumes an immense amount of electric energy to control temperature [35]. In addition, LiFePO4 regenerating process needs an indispensable procedure that Li/Fe molar ratio must be accurately measured before Li2CO3 adding in solid phase roasting [36]. The potential problem of hydrometallurgical leaching lies in the serious environmental pollution caused by residual acid liquor. Thus, although great efforts have been made to regenerate LiFePO4 materials by solid phase roasting or recycle valuable metal from spent LIBs by acid leaching, the current problems of high energy consumption and much residual liquid are still urgently solved.
Herein we reported a novel closed-loop regeneration process simultaneously from scrap LiFePO4 cathode and graphite anode. Hydrothermal reaction is widely applied in the synthesis of various leading materials and compounds with the virtue of homogeneous regular particles with high crystallinity [37]. Graphene has unique characteristics of high electronic conductivity, large surface area and high specific strength [38]. In our work, graphene oxide (GO), recovered from spent graphite anode via Hummers method, was added into LiFePO4 regeneration hydrothermal reaction. Through compensating Li+ into Li-deficient vacancy without considering the Li/Fe ratio and reducing GO to form reduced GO (RGO) simultaneously, highperformance LiFePO4/RGO composite was re-synthesized [39]. Compared with the previous technology of recycling spent LiFePO4 batteries, our research has several major highlights: (1) It is a closed-loop recycling regenerating process that regenerated cathode and anode materials are obtained simultaneously; (2) Different from the traditional sintering method, hydrothermal reaction doesn't require tedious chemical calculation to gain Li/Fe molar ratio, and the repaired LiFePO4 batteries are suitable for various electric current and capacity fading conditions; (3) It is an environmental, low-cost and low-energy process differing in sintering and leaching procedure; (4) The LiFePO4 materials coated with recovered RGO display high electrochemical performance. Hence, this work provides a promising idea to re-synthesis LiFePO4/RGO composite from spent LiFePO4 cathode and graphite anode materials with non-pollution, low cost and high returns, and potentially achieving industrialized EVs/HEVs application.

sections.heading: 2.1. Recycling of cathode and anode materials
sections.text: A closed-loop recycling and regenerating process of disposing spent LiFePO4 battery was shown in Fig. 1 In this experiment, spent LiFePO4 battery of No. 18650, provided from American A123 Systems Co., Ltd., was first discharged to 2.0 V by dipping in 1mol/L of NaCl solution for 24 h and then dismantled to get cathode plates, anode plates, Al shell, electrolyte and separators in sealed box. In following procedure, in order to separate cathode and anode materials, cathode and anode plates were soaked in NaOH solution and dimethylacetamide (DMAC) for 10 h, respectively. Then the spent cathode materials were calcined in air at the temperature of 500 °C for 3 h to get rid of the binder and conducting carbon. It should be pointed that a small amount of generated Li3PO4, Fe2O3 and FePO4 in the calcining process could be resynthesized of LiFePO4 in subsequent hydrothermal process. Finally the above black powders were dried, ball-milled and sieved to obtain spent cathode materials and anode material. Meanwhile the circular regeneration diagram of spent LiFePO4 battery based on environmental assessment on industry is shown in Fig. S1 in the supporting information.

sections.heading: 2.2. Regeneration of cathode and anode materials
sections.text:
In hydrothermal reaction process, spent LiFePO4 powder, LiOH, Lascorbic acid (reducing agent) and dodecyl benzene sulphonic acid sodium (SDBS, C18H29SO3Na) with the molar ratio of 1:3:3:1 were added into 30mL of deionized water. After stirring for 2 h, the solution was transferred into a reaction kettle, heated to 140, 150, 160, 170, 180 °C for 6 h respectively, and the as-prepared samples were denoted as “T-140-6, T-150-6, T-160-6, T-170-6, T-180-6”, respectively. Similarly, the reaction kettle was heated to 160 °C for 4, 5, 6, 7 and 8 h and the samples were designated as “T-160-4, T-160-5, T-160-6, T-1607, T-160-8”, respectively. Regenerated GO from spent graphite anode was added into mixture before the hydrothermal process at temperature of 160 °C for 6 h, and the sample was marked as “5%RGO-T-160-6”. In comparison, spent LiFePO4 cathode material without treatment in the experiment was labeled as “Un-treated”.
The GO-preparing process was shown in Fig. S2 in the supporting information, 1 g spent graphite and 0.5 g NaNO3 were gradually added into a three-necked flask with 23mL concentrated H2SO4 in ice-bath, and then KMnO4 was added slowly into the mixture with the temperature below 3 °C. After stirring for 1 h, three-necked flask was transferred to a water-bath at 38 °C and kept stirring for 1 h. Then 46mL deionized water was added into mixture, and the whole mixture was stirred in another deionized water of 95 °C for 0.5 h. Afterwards 140mL deionized water of 40 °C was added to dilute the mixture and 15mL 30% vol. H2O2 was added to neutralise the residual KMnO4. Finally, the GO powder was obtained after being washed, dispersed and dried.

sections.heading: 2.3. Material characterizations
sections.text:
Surface and crystal structure of LiFePO4 cathode and anode materials were characterized by scanning electron microscope (SEM, SIGLA500, Germany), transmission electron microscopy (TEM, FEI Tecnai G20) and X-ray diffraction (XRD, D8 ADVANCE, BRUKER) with Cu Kα radiation (1.54 Å) at a voltage of 40.0 kV and current 300mA, respectively. Raman spectroscopy was determined by a Renishaw Raman Microscope using the spectra range between 500 and 3500 cm−1 with a 532 nm laser. Inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) was used to test the contents of main metals. Chemical bondings were characterized by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Escalab 250Xi Thermo Fisher Scientific) using an Al Kα radiation (Ephoton=1486.6 eV). Particle size distribution were determined with
particle size analyzer (Malvern, Zetasizer Nano ZS90). The mass content of LiFePO4 in the cathode materials was tested by thermal gravimetric analyzer (TGA, TGA2, METTLER TOLEDO).

sections.heading: 2.4. Electrochemical measurements
sections.text: Cyclic voltammetry (CV) and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) were measured on an electrochemical workstation (Shanghai Chenhua Co., Ltd.) with a scan rate of 0.5 mV s−1 and in the discharged state over the frequency range from 100 kHz to 0.1 Hz with potential amplitude of 5mV, respectively. The working electrodes were prepared by mixing 80wt% LiFePO4 powders, 10 wt% conductive agent (carbon black, Super-P), and 10wt% binder (polyvinylidene difluoride, PVDF), with 1.0M lithium hexafluorophosphate (LiPF6) in EC + DEC + DMC (1:1:1 v/v/v.) as the electrolyte and monolayer polypropylene film (Celgard 2400) as the separator. The mass loading of active materials in the cathode was around 2.98 mg cm2, and the coin cells (2025) were assembled in a high purity argon-filled glove box. The galvanostatic charging/discharging measurements were performed on a voltage window of 2.5–4.2 V using a LAND battery tester. It should be noted that all the calculation of specific capacity is based on the mass of actual active materials (LiFePO4) in cathode material mixture.

sections.heading: 3.1. Material characterizations
sections.text:
Fig. 2a and b and Figs. S3a and b show XRD patterns of LiFePO4 regenerated at different conditions, all of which were analyzed by comparing them with the orthorhombic space group Pnma (JCPDS card No. 83–2092). From the patterns, the peaks of impurity phases, including FePO4, P2O5 and Fe2O3, can be obviously observed in the pattern of spent LiFePO4, while no characteristic peaks of these impurity phases are observed from the patterns of hydrothermally-repaired LiFePO4 cathode materials, indicating the high purity of regenerated LiFePO4. The olivine structure can be deduced from the intensity ratio of I(020)/I(200) [40]. According to the analysis results (shown in Table 1), the I(020)/I(200) ratios of 5%RGO-T-160-6, Un-treated, T-160-8, T-160-7, T-160-6, T-160-5 and T-160-4 are 2.07, 1.66, 1.81, 1.79, 1.80, 1.77 and 1.76, respectively. It is obvious that hydrothermal LiFePO4 cathode materials, especially for 5%RGO-T-160-6, have an increased intensity ratio of I(020)/I(200) compared with spent LiFePO4, which indicates destructive crystals have been repaired in hydrothermal reaction. XRD patterns of spent anode graphite and prepared GO are also displayed in Fig. S4.
Fig. 2c shows the Raman spectra of 5%RGO-T-160-6, Un-treated and T-160-6. Strong Raman peaks at 620 and 1028 cm−1 can be detected from the spectra, which are corresponded with the characteristic vibrations of PO43− in LiFePO4 [41]. Two broad peaks at 1315 and 1584 cm−1 are attributed to the D band and G band of carbon, respectively. In general, the peak intensity ratio A(D)/A(G) of spectra is associated with the degree of disordering of the carbon, where a higher A(D)/AG) ratio indicates a greater degree of disorder in the carbon arrangement. Compared with the A(D)/A(G) ratio of 0.89 for spent LiFePO4, the 5%RGO-T-160-6 and T-160-6 present a ratio of 0.78 and 0.83, which reveals the higher ordering degree of carbon layer, and thus it can improve the electronic conductivity of regenerated LiFePO4. XPS results of 5%RGO-T-160-6 and Un-treated can be observed in Fig. 2d, which show no much difference from Li 1s, C 1s, O 1s, P2p spectra. They only show different peaks of Fe 2p at different positions, corresponding to different valence states of iron from Un-treated sample, while this phenomenon does not present in the sample of 5% RGO-T-160-6. This indicates that LiFePO4 has been recovered well during hydrothermal process, which is consistent with the XRD characterization results. In the XPS spectra of C 1s shown in Fig. S5, the
main fitted peak at 284.5 eV are all displayed for 5%RGO-T-160-6, prepared GO and commercial GO (Ningbo Moxi Technology Co., Ltd.). Besides, the samples all present minor peaks at 286.5–288.3 eV, which peaks of 5%RGO-T-160-6 is weaker than the peaks of prepared GO and commercial GO, confirming that a mass of prepared GO is reduced to RGO in hydrothermal reaction.
The 5%RGO-T-160-6, Un-treated and commercial LiFePO4 powder were heated from 30 °C to 1000 °C in an air atmosphere with the heat rate of 10 °C·min−1 to test the mass content of LiFePO4. In Fig. S6, a significant weight increase of 3.01 wt % for commercial LiFePO4 is found due to the oxidation of Fe2+, and a slight weight loss of 2.52 wt % for 5%RGO-T-160-6 is found due to the burning of RGO and oxidation of Fe2+, and a weight loss of 17.53 wt% for un-treated can be attributed to the decomposition of binder, burning of conducting carbon and oxidation of Fe2+. For these samples after TGA test, all the final products exist as the forms of Li3PO4, Fe2O3 and FePO4, which can be explained as the following equation.

Thus according to the law of conservation of mass, the mass contents of LiFePO4 for 5%RGO-T-160-6 and un-treated are 94.64 wt%
(97.48/103.01×100wt%) and 80.07 wt% (82.47/103.01×100 wt %), respectively. These results reveal that regenerated LiFePO4 of 5% RGO-T-160-6 is coated with around 5% RGO and spent cathode materials consist of 80 wt % spent LiFePO4 powders, 20 wt % conductive agent and binder.
The Li+ compensation of spent and regenerated LiFePO4 was evidenced by the ICP results (shown in Table 2). For the regeneration process, the target ratio of Li/Fe is 1.00 and the impurity phases are required to remove. Compared with the Li/Fe ratio of 0.75 for spent LiFePO4, the ratios of 5%RGO-T-160-6 (1.00), T-160-8 (1.00), T-160-7 (0.99), T-160-6 (1.00), T-160-5 (0.97) and T-160-4 (0.95) are evidently improved, reflecting that hydrothermal repair process can compensate Li+ drastically and does not need to count the ratio of Li/Fe before regenerating spent LiFePO4.

sections.heading: 3.2. Electrochemical performance
sections.text:
To examine the electrochemical characteristics of 5%RGO-T-160-6, T-160-6 and Un-treated, cyclic voltammograms with scan rate of 0.5 mV s−1 in the potential range from 2.5 to 4.2 V (vs. Li+/Li) are
shown in Fig. 3a. It can be obviously seen that a pair of reversible redox peaks all present in the curves, ascribing to the oxidation and reduction of Fe2+/Fe3+. For 5%RGO-T-160-6, T-160-6 and Un-treated, the anodic oxidation/cathodic reduction occurs at 3.63/3.28, 3.64/3.25 and 3.68/ 3.23 V, respectively, corresponding to the lithium ion intercalation and de-intercalation reaction [42]. Apparently, the potential interval between reduction peak and oxidation peak of 5%RGO-T-160-6, T-160-6 and Un-treated are 0.35, 0.39 and 0.45 V, respectively. The smaller potential interval of regenerated LiFePO4 means the excellent electrochemical reversibility, and the reactivity of hydrothermally-repaired LiFePO4 can be achieved by lithium compensation and crystal recovery.
Fig. 3b–f displays the electrochemical impedance spectra and related results of regenerated LiFePO4 and spent LiFePO4 batteries after 10, 50 and 100 charge-discharge cycles. Generally, the semicircle in high frequency region is arised from the charge-transfer resistance (Rct) and a straight line in low frequency region from the diffusion-controlled Warburg impedance (Ws). In the artificial circuit, the additional symbols of Rs and CPE represent ohmic resistance of the electrolyte/electrode and double layer capacitance, respectively. It can be seen from
Table S1 that Rct value of 5%RGO-T-160-6 (91.40Ω) is much smaller than that of Un-treated (431.81Ω), and lithium ion diffusion coefficients D value of 5%RGO-T-160-6 (7.48×10−10 cm2s−1) is much greater than that of Un-treated (8.56× 10−11 cm2s−1) after 100 cycles, indicating that RGO coating and hydrothermal recovery can remarkably improve the electronic conductivity and lithium ion diffusivity. It can also be clearly observed from Table S1 that Rct value and D value of 5%RGO-T-160-6 have not changed too much after prolonged cycling, compared with Un-treated, reflecting the highly stable properties of the electrochemical reaction in 5%RGO-T-160-6.
Fig. 4a and Fig. S7a show the charge-discharge curves of spent and regenerated LiFePO4 at 0.2C with a cut-off potential window of 2.5–4.2 V. The voltage-capacity profiles of the spent and regenerated LiFePO4 all display voltage flat plateaus at 3.4–3.5 V. However compared with spent LiFePO4, hydrothermally repaired LiFePO4 presents higher charge-discharge specific capacity and lower potential interval, implying that spent LiFePO4 suffers from a larger polarization loss and irreversible reaction owing to Li-deficiency, crystal-destruction and impurity phases. Among regenerated LiFePO4 without doping of RGO,
it is clearly observed that charge-discharge specific capacities of T-1608, T-160-7 and T-160-6 (T-180-6, T-170-6 and T-160-6) are higher than that of T-160-5 and T-160-4 (T-150-6 and T-140-6), demonstrating that the LiFePO4 of T-160-5 and T-160-4 (T-150-6 and T-140-6) are not repaired completely due to insufficient hydrothermal time and temperature. From Fig. 4b and Figs. S7b and a decreasing coulombic efficiency of spent LiFePO4 gradually shows after long-term cycling at
0.2 C, while those of regenerated LiFePO4 still remain over 98% (over 99% for 5%RGO-T-160-6). Fig. 4c and d presents the electrochemical performance of spent and regenerated LiFePO4 when charged/discharged at 0.2C for 100 cycles. The initial discharge capacities of 5% RGO-T-160-6, Un-treated, T-160-8, T-160-7, T-160-6, T-160-5 and T160-4 (T-180-6, T-170-6, T-150-6 and T-140-6) deliver about 163.3, 110.9, 153.6, 152.8, 154.9, 139.6 and 131.3 mAhg−1 (153.9, 154.2,
142.1 and 132.2 mAhg−1), respectively. It can be simply found that T160-8, T-160-7 and T-160-6 (T-180-6, T-170-6 and T-160-6) have better electrochemical performance than those of T-160-5 and T-160-4 (T150-6 and T-140-6). Thereby, hydrothermal reaction is kept at 160 °C for 6 h as an optimum hydrothermal condition. After 100 cycles, the capacity retention ratios of 5%RGO-T-160-6, Un-treated and T-160-6 are 99.63%, 85.84% and 97.29%, respectively, demonstrating that RGO-coating and hydrothermal repair improve the cycling performance of spent LiFePO4 batteries effectively. Meanwhile as shown in Fig. 4e and Fig. S7c, the cycling performances of 5%RGO-T-160-6 at 1C also display better. Fig. 4g presents the prolonged cycling performances of 5%RGO-T-160-6 and Un-treated at 0.5C. The discharge capacity of 5% RGO-T-160-6 is around 150.4 mAhg−1 in the first cycle and remains stable till 300 cycles, while the initial capacity of Un-treated is only around 103.8 mAhg−1 and continuously declining throughout subsequent cycles, explaining that hydrothermal regenerated LiFePO4 keep excellent electrochemical performance in long cycling test.
In order to analyze the charge and discharge properties at different current densities, Fig. 4f and Fig. S7d show the rate performance of spent and regenerated LiFePO4. When cycled at the current densities of 0.2, 0.5, 1, 2 and 5C, 5%RGO-T-160-6 delivers discharge capacities of around 162.8, 157.4, 147.9, 138.4 and 121.5 mAhg−1, while for Untreated, they are only 108.5, 103.8, 95.6, 87.4 and 72.2 mAhg−1. From the results, it can be unambiguously seen that the electrochemical performance of regenerated LiFePO4, especially for 5%RGO-T-160-6, is significantly improved at different current densities.

sections.heading: 3.3. Structure characterizations
sections.text:
It can be seen from the SEM images (shown in Fig. 5) that the particle morphology of spent LiFePO4 electrode presents obviously irregular with a large number of agglomeration phenomena and uneven particle. The images display a lot of rods caused by the aggregation of carbon and discarded adhesive. Previous studies have confirmed that the residue of a small amount of adhesive will not affect the
regeneration of batteries and subsequent electrochemical performance [20]. However, the agglomeration of LiFePO4 electrode after regeneration is greatly reduced, and the particles become finer and more uniform. This is due to the energy in the hydrothermal process that leads to structural remodelling and particle fusion. The morphology and particle size of regenerated LiFePO4 at different hydrothermal temperatures and time are shown in Fig. S8. The results show that the morphology of the electrode treated by hydrothermal process all can be reshaped and changed obviously. Moreover it can be seen that the material obtained at the temperature of 160 °C for 6 h presents more uniform morphology and more concentrated particle size distribution than other at other temperatures. The morphology of graphene oxide obtained from regeneration of anode electrode is also shown in Fig. 5d, which shows clear layered structure. Eventually the regenerated LiFePO4/graphene composite can be seen as the form of the even LiFePO4 distribution between graphene layers.
Furthermore, from the TEM/HRTEM images (shown in Fig. 6a and b), the regenerated LiFePO4 and graphene composite materials show obvious graphene nanoribbons covering the surface of LiFePO4, which reveals that the composite mode of LiFePO4 and graphene is not only LiFePO4 distributing in the interlayer structure of graphene, but also the graphene evenly covering on the surface of the particles. Meanwhile in Fig. 6c and d, the lattice structure can be calculated from lattice fringe through Digital-Micrograph software analysis. They are shown as 1.601 Å and 2.364 Å respectively in the images, corresponding to the (521) crystal surface of LiFePO4 and the (104) crystal surface of FePO4, which proves again that the impurity phase FePO4 was generated during the charge-discharge cycles. It is also clear from the results of mapping that the carbon elements are mainly distributed on the rod, and on the outer edges of the particles after the coating from the regenerated RGO. And Fe, O, P and other elements show signs of uniform distribution.

sections.heading: 3.4. Regenerating mechanism of spent LiFePO4
sections.text:
Based on XRD, XPS, ICP, SEM, TEM/HRTEM results, the structure of spent LiFePO4 cathode material displays several flaws, including loss of Li+, formation of impurity phases, particle agglomeration, structure transformation and collapse. Nevertheless these problems can be solved in hydrothermal process and it is speculated that the following equation occurs in hydrothermal reaction:

Based on the above analysis, a cathode/anode regenerating mechanism of spent LiFePO4 battery was proposed, as shown in Fig. 7. After long-term charge-discharging cycling, the crystal structure of LiFePO4 cathode material gradually appears Li+ deficiency and crystal destruction, thereby decreasing efficiency of Li+ intercalation and deintercalation. As shown in Fig. S9, crystal destruction includes structure collapse, atomic migration and unknown structure formation, such as combination of olivine structure between original/destructive FeO6 and original/destructive PO4 in spent LiFePO4. However during the hydrothermal reaction, the ions are compensated to Li-deficient vacancy of crystals and crystal destruction can be restored by the means of
hydrothermal repair. Similarly, after long-term cycling, interlayer force of graphite anode decreases due to Li+ intercalation and de-intercalation. Therefore, this graphite is more easily than commercial graphite to prepare GO via Hummers method. In hydrothermal reaction, RGO gained by reducing GO is coated on repaired LiFePO4 to improve their electrochemical performance.

sections.heading: 3.5. Comparison of hydrothermal and solid-state methods
sections.text:
In order to contrast the advantages and disadvantages of the hydrothermal regeneration and traditional solid phase regeneration, the electrochemical properties of batteries manufactured by the regenerated LiFePO4 materials obtained by these two methods are compared in details, as shown in Fig. 8. Among them, the regenerated
LiFePO4 material from solid phase method was obtained through roasting spent LiFePO4 at 650 °C for 2 h with adding appropriate amount of Li2CO3 and the sample was designated as “C-650-2”. From the XRD patterns, no characteristic peaks of impurity phases are observed for both hydrothermal and solid phase methods, indicating the both high purity of regenerated LiFePO4. Meanwhile in the SEM images, the regenerated LiFePO4 from solid phase method appears obvious sheet structure, much agglomeration and larger particle size, which are very different compared to spherical structure, less agglomeration and smaller particle size from hydrothermal regeneration. As to electrochemical properties of the regenerated LiFePO4 materials, the LiFePO4 battery from hydrothermal process shows more flat voltage plateaus, higher discharge capacity, more stable cycle performance than those of LiFePO4 battery regenerated from solid phase method.
Based on the above comparison, the regenerated LiFePO4/RGO composite from hydrothermal method shows spherical morphology, smaller and more uniform particles and exhibits better reversible capacity, high columbic efficiency, stable cycle performance and excellent rate capacity, which is much beneficial for the booming EVs/HEVs application in the nearer future. In order to further contrast the industrialization application, the computer aided design (CAD) diagrams of the industrial process of two methods are proposed as shown in Fig. S10. The diagrams show the main equipments used by different methods, including large-scale autoclave, plate filter, vacuum double cone drier and ball mill machine in hydrothermal process, and feeding conveying system, ball mill machine, preheater, electrical heating plate kiln in solid phase roasting process. Obviously, the equipment sets used in solid phase roasting process are much more than those in the hydrothermal process. For example, there need many ball mills and preheaters to treat raw materials in solid phase roasting process.
Based on the above comparison, in order to further demonstrate the economic benefits of solid phase method and hydrothermal method, the relevant economic analysis was carried out according to a 1000 t/a output of LiFePO4. sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
In a sum, spent LiFePO4 cathode material was regenerated through Li+ compensation and structure reshaping via hydrothermal method, and then graphene oxide recovered from spent graphite anode via Hummers method was added to synthesize LiFePO4/RGO composite. The XRD, RS, XPS, ICP results reveal that the impurity phases and destructive crystals of spent LiFePO4 cathode and graphite anode were both repaired in hydrothermal reaction. The as-regenerated LiFePO4/ RGO composite displays better electrochemical performance, including smooth CV curves, low electrochemical impedance, high capacity, flat voltage plateau, high columbic efficiency, stable cycle performances at 0.2C and 1C and excellent rate capacity. The SEM, TEM/HRTEM images show that the regenerated LiFePO4/RGO composite shows spherical morphology, smaller and more uniform particles. The composite mode of LiFePO4 and graphene includes LiFePO4 distributing in the interlayer structure of graphene and the graphene evenly covering on the surface of the particles. Finally through comparison, the regenerated LiFePO4/ RGO composites from hydrothermal process shows better properties than those of regenerated LiFePO4 from solid phase roasting method whatever electrochemical properties or economical efficiency in the booming EVs/HEVs industrialization.

metadata.abstractText: Currently extensive attentions on application of LiFePO4 batteries in electric vehicles are attracted to the researchers. Owing to the high cost of raw materials and burdensome preparation process, the re-synthesis of LiFePO4 from spent batteries becomes an economical and convenient way. Herein, a novel closed-loop regeneration process simultaneously from spent LiFePO4 cathode and graphite anode is proposed. Spent LiFePO4 cathode material is first successfully regenerated through Li compensation and structure reshaping via hydrothermal method, and then graphene oxide is recovered from spent graphite anode via Hummers method. The as-regenerated LiFePO4/reduced graphene oxide composites present spherical morphology, smaller and more uniform particles. The composite mode of LiFePO4 and graphene includes LiFePO4 distributing in the interlayer structure of graphene and the graphene evenly covering on the surface of the particles. The regenerated LiFePO4/reduced graphene oxide batteries exhibit reversible capacities of 162.6 mAhg and high columbic efficiency, stable cycle performances at 0.2 and 1C and excellent rate capacity. Through comparison, the regenerated LiFePO4/reduced graphene oxide composites from hydrothermal process shows better prosperities than those of regenerated LiFePO4 from solid phase roasting method whatever electrochemical properties or economical efficiency in the booming electric vehicles and hybrid electric vehicles industrialization.
